response.answer_text: Writing MBA essays and statements can be more than a little intimidating, but there are definitely a few things you can do to get your application to the top of the pile. 1. Answer the question! It sounds obvious, but it's pretty easy to get off track from the topic or to answer a question you feel more comfortable with than the original question posed. However, it's very important not to get derailed! Get to the point as quickly as you can, and be relevant throughout the essay. Make sure you have a clear structure and a logical flow of thought. 2. Be specific to the school and the question posed. When you (inevitably) have to explain why you chose a particular institution, there should be a clear correlation between your reasons and the school. Don't make the common mistake of submitting the same application to different places and simply swapping out the names! The letter will come across as too general because you've crafted the statement to fit multiple places while changing just a few key phrases. They won't absolutely know, but they will suspect. Even worse, you're proving to yourself that you don't have what it takes to write a few separate documents, and that's not only lazy, it's a little insulting to the addressee. 3. Follow the rules. If there's a word count, do not go over, under any circumstances. If they want a specific font type or size, just do it. If they want a certain file type, make sure you save your document to match. Little details like this are the first step to getting your document through the door and onto the desks of the application committee members. If there's a time to color inside the lines, it's now!  4. Be personal. Don't talk about rising tuition costs in America; talk about how you had worked two jobs and still completed your final year of undergraduate education. Don't turn it into a sob story, but talk about how it was all worth it, or how it made you who you are today. Focus on unique experiences that will set you apart from the thousands of other applicants to the school. 5. Don't go overboard with the enthusiasm. Always remain professional. Show that you have energy and passion, that you are committed, and that you are unique. However, be humble. Unique does not mean "the best." What makes your point of view your very own? That's what you want to demonstrate. 6. Make sure there's some mention of your achievements and the challenges you've overcome. Show that you are well rounded. What are your accomplishments in academia? Athletics? The arts? Make sure the achievements you mention are current and professional. 7. It's okay to keep it simple. Drop the dramatics. The jargon, the academic language, and the stuffy personality all have to go. Show your personality! If you're funny, be funny. (If you're not, though, this probably isn't the place to practice.) Just be yourself. Maybe you're sensitive. Talk about how you learned to accept criticism, and prove that it's something you've developed. 8. Don't ever give excuses or apologize. So you have a bad mark or a year in which you did nothing at all. Even though there are always explanations for doing poorly, they should never be used as excuses. Address your mistakes, and talk about what you've learned. 9. Edit the essay. It's not worth risking a blatant grammar error, as that can become the main thing a reviewer remembers about your application. Even if you have flawless grammar and spelling, perhaps you can work on clarity, tone, or structure.

From the past several years I have come across many students who might have for what it takes getting into a premium University, but at the same time a matter of fact is that they could just be “another candidate” fulfilling the admission requirements for applying to that particular University. So it is all about what you show you have, and this part of application gives you the proper ground for the same. Essays/ SOP is the heart of your application, as you are directly introducing yourself to the adcom in a written format, and thus considering what the University wants in your profile you must make sure you hit the bulls eye. For writing a perfect statement you can consider the following steps: Be yourself, as an original is always worth more than a copy.It’s the opening of the letter which will grab attention so ensure it is strong and articulate.Highlighting the strengths and assets of your profile, I repeat highlighting the strengths and assets of your profile is the most important aspect of your candidature.Precision, honesty and clarity should be the strong points of your SOP.Remember to convey your goals and how MBA program will take you closer to those goals.The committee should be made aware of your skills and interests.Your shortcomings should also be conveyed across in a subtle manner. For example if you had an average GPA or a poor GPA in your freshman year, it should be put across in a cryptic way, along with mentioning how it has improved over the time.For a particular Essay question, you must answer it with suitable examples from your past experiences.When you write an SOP for MBA the focus should be to describe the information which is relevant to your past events and connect it with the next possible steps you seek. Your work participation, the place you have worked, duration of work and what you gained from it are a few areas which are to be emphasized. Work exposure contributes greatly in shaping your personality and accentuating your persona.There is no room for errors, spelling mistakes or poor English while you write SOP for MBA.The SOP should not exceed more than 2 pages (unless guided otherwise), content should be double spaced with 1 inch margins and in Times New Roman 12 points font (preferred).To sum up, the way you are brought up, your experiences and the environment that you live makes you resonate different than every other being, and so does your story. And thus the unique path you come from, which has solidified your current goal must be beautifully connected and presented correctly.

Creating a good essay can be a pretty hard work for many candidates willing to enter top management education institutions. However, if they are ready to find some time, specify their aims, think about their achievements and follow simple instructions, then they will have all chances to write a paper that lets them get a foot in the doors of many colleges. An essay is a tool which lets the admissions department get to know the candidates better. Even though creating an essay may seem to be an easy task from the first sight, there are a few important directions to follow to create a standout paper. Think About an Essay In Advance Allocate some time for reflection before starting to write a paper. Most programs ask candidates to write several essays. So, it is important to start researching specific questions long before brainstorming. Don’t hesitate to create two separate lists where you will indicate all your plans and achievements and name the schools and programs you want to enroll in. Mention Your Achievements Sometimes, boasting about yourself may seem to be a sign of a mean person. But this has nothing to do with an MBA paper. However, make sure that you don’t look like a braggart. Focus on the good things you have done and achieved, and convince the staff that you are going to be a good student. MBA personal statement is always a hit-or-miss thing. Here are some tips to help your MBA essay get a hit: Be sincere. Believe it or not but admissions officers are like lie busters. They can easily tell an honest applicant from the one who is just trying to seem such. And if they spot a liar, his/her essay will get straight to the rejected pile.Tell them about your goals. Your goals are part of your personality. And that is exactly what admissions committee wants to see in your essay. Write about your achievements and future goals. Show the connections between them and the way you took to reach them.Say why you are a good fit for them. Naturally, once you’ve decided to enter particular b-school, admissions officers want to know why. What can you offer them? In what way you fit the program you are going to get into.

Strong and successful have some key common characteristics which include: 1. They showcase a well-rounded applicant – Each essay covers a different aspect of your personality/experiences/interests, and the top schools demand that you are actively engaged at: (a) the individual level – this is most clearly represented through exposure to different art and media (books, music and film), as well as through travel and work experiences (b) at the academic level – subjects that you are currently proficient with, what you’re doing for supplemental learning outside the classroom, academic rigor and subject choices for the undergraduate level (c) at the community level –Strong knowledge on current affairs to active community involvement at the local, national or international level 2. Content, Content, Content – Content is the crux of the essays. It is important for you to check for content at each stage of the writing process. As the content is refined, it is easier for the structure and language to automatically fall into place. Don’t overlap content across the application – use the essays to showcase different sides of you. 3. Keeping it simple – The essay is crisp, the content is strong and the question is clearly answered. You need to show that you can competently organize your thought process, make a persuasive argument and articulate yourself in a coherent manner. 4. A high level of maturity – Admissions committees are looking for students that display an outstanding level of maturity, so this needs to permeate through your content, focus on supporting opinions with evidence, as well as stylization. Please ensure, however, that you maintain your integrity and individuality at all times, but also make sure that you do not seem as though you are taking yourself too seriously. 5. They Make sure you answers the question – make sure you read the essay topic over and over again. Answer exactly what the prompt asks and in the word limit specified. Remember – it’s a limit and you cannot exceed it. And of course it goes without saying they are void of silly mistakes and, grammatical errors. So make sure you proof read multiple times. Essays are your best chance to share a great story about you. It is a great opportunity for you to convince the admissions committee that you are a perfect fit for the school.
